awd_titl_txt: Optimal and Adaptive p-Value Combination Methods with Application to ALS Exome Sequencing Study
awd_abstract_narration:
Statistical theory and methodology play a key role in advancing scientific research. The p-value combination approach is a foundational statistical method for important data-driven research in meta-analysis, data integration, and signal detection.  Despite recent theoretical and methodological advances, significant gaps still exist in the literature.  Many of the assumptions including independence, Gaussianity, and large group size, are not realistic for real data applications.  Further, some methods developed based on ad hoc arguments lack a rigorous study of optimality.  This project seeks to develop new methods that exhibit more powerful and robust performance.  The methods will be applied to the analysis of large exome sequencing data from a study of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).  Students from underrepresented groups will be strongly encouraged to participate in this project. 

The objective of this project is to develop powerful and robust p-value combination tests that are optimal and data-adaptive under a wide spectrum of signal patterns and readily applicable to real data analysis.  Analytical calculations for p-value and statistical power, and asymptotic techniques, under realistic assumptions of small or moderate group size, non-Gaussian distribution, dependence, and linear-model-based alternative hypotheses, will be developed.  Two statistics families, gGOF for goodness-of-fit type tests, and tFisher for Fisher type p-value combination, will be investigated.  In addition to a study of power and optimality, the project will also develop omnibus tests for adapting to unknown signal patterns.  The project will lead to (1) a new statistical framework for calculating the distributions of generic families of goodness-of-fit type and Fisher type statistics, (2) optimal statistics for given signal patterns as well as data-adaptive methods when patterns are unknown, and (3) genetic association test strategies for detecting genetic effects.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of this statistical research project is to develop p-value combination testing methods that are optimal and adaptive to a broad spectrum of signal patterns under realistic data properties. The research and development are critical to analyzing big cutting-edge data, e.g., in modern genetics and genomics. Following this goal, we planned tasks on theoretical studies, methodology development, computational implementation, and real-data assessment and application. At the end of this project, we completed the vast majority of these tasks and achieved the goal. The outcomes include novel statistical theory, methodology, and applications published in over ten research articles in top journals in relevant fields. We also published four software (R) packages on the official website of The Comprehensive R Archive Network (CRAN). The new methods also helped discover several putative genetic factors of Crohn's disease, osteoporosis, and ALS. The results have also been disseminated to statistics and human genetics communities through talks and seminars in professional conferences and invited visits. These project outcomes have moved forward statistics in the field of p-value combination theory and methodology, which will likely boost scientific discoveries in the genetics of complex human diseases. The outcomes also include the broader impact of the research, which provided opportunities for training and professional development. In particular, this project partially supported four Ph.D. students (two females). It provided research opportunities for 22 undergraduate and master?s students in their major qualifying projects (MQP) and research capstone projects at Worcester Polytechnic Institute. The PI advised in the Summer Research Experience program in Bioinformatics and Computational Biology (BCB) for high school students. The research also enriched educational materials in Applied Statistics, Statistics, and BCB at WPI. Underrepresented minorities were encouraged and included in related research activities.
